review_body: To be honest the first time I did the capsule hotel thing I was a bit nervous. I did it because you have to try it once in Tokyo. However, after the 1st time I booked the Nine Hours in Shinjuku I booked another night. Now, two years later I'm back and this place hasn't changed it's awesome. Super efficient just what a solo traveler wants. I want my time spent out exploring Tokyo. When I come back to my accommodation I don't need a room, the locker holds my backpack and they can store your larger luggage, no extra charge. The solid shower before heading to the airport is worth the stay. Large bathroom with an awesome clean shower and everything you need to get your day started. I came here for the experience and left as a lifetime customer.

I stayed at 9hours for 2 nights. The hotel is really modern and clean. The checkin checkout process went quickly and the staff is very friendly!The room : capsules are clean and comfortable, there is a light and plug to charge your phone. The capsules are not isolated, you can hear everything thats happening in the room, if you’re unlucky and have to sleep with noisy people it could be a bit annoying. But most of people are very respectfull. Keep in mind it’s a hostel you can’t require full silence.The bathroom: is very modern, there are a lot of toilets and showers, no need to wait for your turn!Maybe they should put some music in the bathrooms. I understand the bedrooms should be quiet but the Silent Vibe in the bathroom is a bit creepy.. ( but that’s just my vibe, I put music everywhere I go)Breakfast: If you add I think 3 euros you have breakfast included in your stay. Breakfast is not at the hostel it’s in a restaurant 1 min from the hostel. I would not recommend it. It’s not the best breakfast and I think the area offers so much more food to discover than to go to this place.Lobby: it’s a comfortable place to chill/work/chat. I think it’s a good hotel for 1 or 2 nights but not for a long time because you can not unpack. Your luggage stays in the lockers so you have to be a bit organized (preparing your clothes for the next day, your bathroom amenities to go shower,..). The hotel provides towels , a pijama slippers and toothbrush, soap etc which is really cool!Overall very nice experience , I would totally recommend!

Very nice capsule hotel.Location is nice and easily reachable if you are flying from Haneda or Narita.Low price. Capsule are large enough.Really clean.Staff great.Only negative point: the mattress are thin.Don’t expect comfort. But definitely not big deal.I would go back, no doubt.

Nine Hours was recommended to me and as my visit to Robot Restaurant was late, I wanted somewhere simple to stay. Nine Hours certainly accommodated that. From the very entrance, this place oozes simplicity, futuristic styling and good service. Elevator takes you to the 8th floor where you check-in with staff who have a reasonable grasp of the English language. They explain how Nine Hours works e.g. if you're staying more than one night you check out at 10 and check back in later. The 'all women' capsules are on the 6th floor however, the showers are on another level (I didn't need them). As soon as you get out of the elevator on the 6th floor, there are lockers for your gear, toilets and handbasins. The capsules are through another door that indicates "quiet". If you have trouble climbing up a few stairs, ask for a capsule on the floor level. There are slipon slippers for each capsule which you dispose of before you leave. I crawled into mine, pulled the blind down to give me some privacy and just soaked up the peace. First thing I noticed was how clean it was and no odours or smells. Nice. There are two small shelves moulded into the capsule which are useful for putting your devices while they charge (note that the plug is a little tricky - put your plug in a small way, then turn sideways 90 degrees and push). If found the mattress a little hard but the pillow just fine. Unfortunately for me being tall, the doona (duvet) was a little short. There is very little outside noise, really the only sound is the airconditioning maintaining a constant temperature. Once people started arriving to bed down for the night it got noisy. Consider it a funky dormitory. You can hear people coming and going, snoring, coughing etc. but there is the privacy of your capsule that makes it interesting. It also feels very safe being amongst just women. Check out was quick and simple. There is a large space on the 8th floor where you can look at views of Shinjuku from the floor to ceiling windows both north and south. That, along with a massive table, benches and chairs, there is plenty of time to catch up on work if you need to. It's modern and sparse but somewhat inviting. Located within the Korean District and not from the Robot Restaurant, there is plenty to see and do in and around Nine Hours. I would highly recommend a visit.

This place is fantastic for short stays. It accommodates for anything you might need in transit, it is very clean and everything is considered in detail. Also, the staff are super friendly and helpful :)Just remember, it is called 9h because it is only open for 9. You still have to check out at 10am and can check back in at 1pm, if you are staying longer than one night.

My friend and I visited Shinjuku on yesterday and we stayed at this location! It’s location is the middle of all the action yet once you’re inside it’s a great break. The staff were friendly and spoke a little English which was helpful with directions etc. The showers are on another floor which was a bit of a task, and there weren’t outlets at each mirror. I enjoyed my stay and it was perfect for my short stay in Shinjuku.

I was curious to stay for one night of my solo trip to Tokyo in a capsule, and this was kept surfacing as a good option. I'm so glad I chose to stay here! It was so clean, so quiet and I honestly slept so much better than I'd anticipated. This was perfect for a one-night capsule experience, and I would recommend to anyone looking to do the same.

if you're a bit organized for capsule hotel, for 1-2 nights is very nice. the hotel is young, cheap and clean. the showers are quite big. there is no air conditioned in the capsule. check in and out are very fast

I was always curious to try a capsule hotel and it was much more comfortable than what I was thinking. Also, I was amazed by how clean and organized the shared facilities was! There are plenty of shower rooms and toilets and all are very clean and comfortable to use. This may look like a bag packer choice but has very high standards. The neighborhood is Korean town, full of restaurants and Korean-pop shops and lots of teenagers hanging around.

Everything is kept immaculately clean, the bathrooms are in top shape, and the pods are incredibly comfortable and clean. The staff and friendly, helpful and speak good English. The location is great. Each day you receive a “starter pack with toothbrush, towel, slippers and Pajamas. My only comment would be to ask guests if they’d like slippers and a toothbrush as people are becoming increasingly conscious about waste. Thank you for an incredible stay 9 hours!

I visited Tokyo for 7 nights and I decided to try the famous capsule hotel (it was a must). The concept is great and very easy to check-in and out. The capsule is very big for one person and it does not feel claustrophobic at all. This specific hotel is a very short walk to the main area of Shinjuku. If you get breakfast included, the cafe is few seconds walk, down the main road. The only thing I didn't like is the fact that you have to change where the lockers are, there is no changing room. You can always change inside the shower room but, it is a bit hot and not very comfortable to do so there.

Everything (sleeping pod, mattress, pillow, shower, pajamas, towels) was pretty good except there was only one power socket which is pretty bad because I needed to charge a lot of things (phone, power bank, camera's battery, laptop) and you have to checkout (before 10:00 until 13:00) every day so you can't leave anything charging at that time. I left before 10am and returned back only around midnight so no charging but at least can check in that late.

Stayed one night just to say “I did it.” The capsule was nice and cozy. Very clean and very quiet. Staff was great and provided adequate information about the hotel. Would recommend as part of the complete Japan experience at least once.

New York City, New York

review_body: This capsule hotel offers something fun and exciting for guests who are not used to this type of accommodation. It’s like staying in a hostel but with added privacy and convenience. I’d definitely recommend this for someone in the area.

The fault is really mine as I thought for some reason I needed to experience a capsule hotel thinking it was somehow different from any other accommodation I'd stayed. I have actually stayed in something similar before - it's called a hostel. That's really what it is so if you're like me thinking you need to try a capsule hotel to complement your Japan experience, don't. It's not really the hostel's fault - it's the idiot/inconsiderate guests who stay there; wheeling in their bags at all hours of the night making noise when you're meant to make use of the space and lockers outside the sleeping area, alarms going off in the morning etc. you just have a thin blind to close your pod so you hear EVERYTHING with at least 20 other pods in the sleeping area. The pod was a bit hot (I need to sleep with a window open or a fan blowing or air con etc. so this was a bit stressful initially). I appreciate I might be sounding a bit like a diva but I've done my hostel time and coming off an 8 hour flight it was really not my best idea. Luckily I was checking into a proper hotel for the rest of my stay so I was out like a flash the next morning. If you're young and travelling around and budgeting with hostels - then go for gold, but if you're like me - give it a miss. Seriously.

It was a great experience. It is really near to the subway. The capsules are unbelievable beautiful and all the facilities are nice. The restroom, bathroom and capsules are very clean and the breakfast although is not in the same place is very close and tasty. If you will stay longer than one day, it is a little boring that you need to checkout (and checkin) each day and leave the place until 1PM but besides that, it is a lovely experience. I totaly recommend.

Sparse but surprisingly comfortable. Would definitely stay here again! One thing I would say is to be sure you’re ok with shared facilities. Some people may not enjoy that. Other Th an that, it was a nice sleep and the other guests were courteous.

Clean, stylish design and near station, however there is no elevator nor escalator at the nearest station (新大久保 Shin Okubo), people with heavy luggage please note. Check in and common area are too crowded. Pillow is very flat and hard, the cabin is quite hot. There is one elevator from ground to lobby, another one to ladies floor and one to mens' floor, have to wait for a long time. Provide amenities, towels and sleep wears. Lockers are big and good but there is no space for you to open your luggage for packing!You have to check out every morning at 10am even if you stay for more than one night. You cannot access your capsule and bathroom before check in time!There is no drinking water, no pantry at the hostel!Its pricey, double the price of other hostels.

The staff was very helpful and the place was very clean, will visit here again! The pod was more spacious then I thought and the view from the 8th floor was a very nice extra, enough places to load your phone, must do for alone travelers

Excellent facilities. Very fun futuristic clean looking capsules.Nice staff. (Seemed to listened to good music, sonic youth, etc).Found the location outside is a bit overcrowded for the little sidewalk and annoying to walk through.... but very close to JR station and line that loops around the city, as well as some fun neighbourhoods / areas.You have to check out every morning for cleaning (pretty standard), but can leave stuff in the locker. You receive slippers/toothbrush/paste/towel/pjs every night.

During my visit to Japan, I stayed in two nine hrs hostels - Shinjuku Tokyo and Namba Osaka. Decided to stay in Osaka after having enjoyed my stay at Shinjuku.Both the places were very centrally located, just few minutes walk from metro. What strikes you first is the spotlessly clean place. They provide 2 towels and night wear. Spacious locker is part of the deal. I was early in Osaka and could leave my luggage at the place.The check in was very prompt and professional.When I visit Japan again, I will be happy to stay at 9 hours.

Reasonable for a solo short stay. Provided with towel slippers PJs and toothbrush.Spacious and comfortable capsule.Clean. Location one stop from Shinjuku on Yamanote line - To Shin Okubu.Korean townCons : Alarms early morning can be disturbing

It was my first time in Japan and I came alone. I could have not chose a better place to stay.Right in the middle of Shinjuku district, with a lot of supermarkets, cafes, restaurants, souvenirs shops and metro/train stations.Inside the hotel, very good environment. Everything, and I mean everything, is super clean! For me, cleanliness is my main concern regarding a hotel. The capsules/pods are bigger than they look. And very comfortable too. We have towels (a big and a small one), slippers and a pijama. We don't need to worry with that. So, if one day I return to Tokyo, I will definitely stay here again!

9hours hotel is a beautiful capsule hotel. Large common room for sitting, talking, and figuring out your next move in the vast city. Very quiet which is what you would like especially when tired and traveling solo. They accepted a reservation for me to come in at 1am which was amazing as I was super stressed and tired. Capsules are spacious. I'm 6'2" and had no problem climbing up into the capsule, sitting up when I needed to, and shifting around whilst sleeping. Only one plug for charging devices but if you manage your stuff well you'll be fine. Last but not least the hotel staff are very curtious and amazing. I left something in the locker and they let me go get into locker twice after I checked out. I'm kind of a forgetful person. Will stay again if ever I need a place.Arigato!

We had to stay there for the experience and it was worth it.Extremely clean facilities very well run, fantastic pricePods are quite spaciousLocation is very goodToilets, showers and locker rooms are clean and modern Wouldn’t recommend staying there for more than a couple of nights it becomes tiresome having your luggage stored away from the sleeping quarters so it’s a bit tricky organizing things. But over all we really really enjoyed it, it was a fun experience

It was everything great. Good room, good shower, good attendants. Well located in the city, good restaurants nearby. Metro is nearby.すべてが素晴らしかった。 良い部屋、良いシャワー、良いアテンダント。 市内にあり、近くに良いレストランがあります。 地下鉄が近くにあります。

The capsules are large and comfy, and they give you a cute pack of pajamas, toothbrush and slippers to wear. The only negative is that the lockers are too small for my luggage to fit, but they have luggage storage anyway

A really nice and modern capsule hotel. Capsules much more spacious than expected, and very comfortable. All amenities provided, including pyjamas and towels. If you want to rent more of these there is a cheap price for it. Nice staff on the desk!

Easy check in by friendly staff who straight away provide you with a bag containing towel, slippers, toothbrush and pyjamas. Capsules are extremely modern and spacious and more comfortable than expected! View from rest area onto Shinjuku is an added bonus on top of the central location.

I have always wanted to try staying in a capsule hotel but never had the chance to. Finally did it 2 days ago. Firstly, I love the design of the place. Its classic black and white minimalist design was simple and elegant. Secondly, they provide everything you need to stay the night. I literally drop by without luggage (left everything in another hotel) and they provided everything required for a comfortable rest. PJs, toothbrush tooth paste etc. My only gripe is, perhaps they could provide moisturizers in the ladies bathroom? I think it would really be appreciated. Thirdly, the pod is larger than expected. The mattress though thin was firm and the solo pillow provided support for a good rest.Overall, I love the place, though a later check out time would have been nice. My only concern: when I arrived at 2am in the morning, I was given a key. When I accessed the locker, I found someone's bag etc in the locker. I went back to reception and was issued another key to an empty locker. Fortunately I didn't have any luggage with me. I would not have felt safe leaving my luggage in the locker as I had my laptop etc with me. 9 hours owns a chain of capsule hotels. They look like they pay attention to details judging from the renovation of the place. They will do much better if their staff are also careful with pods/lockers management.

Had an incredible stay here. Just as an experience of the efficiency of Tokyo, I’d recommend staying here.Staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. Pods are clean, well ventilated and mattress gave a good rest.

my first capsule experience in japan! very clean and simple design, and honestly the capsule bed itself was more spacious than I thought. conviently located near shin-okubo station. will come back during my next trip!

The minimalist architecture and design is very eye-catching and elegant. There is a common space near the reception where you can eat, browse the internet or have a chat with friends. Check-in and check-out is quite efficient, which is even better because you have to check out every day before 10am while the hotel is being cleaned. Location is 10/10, only a 2 minute walk from Shin-Okubo station and surrounded by food, shops and convenience stores. You could spend an entire day exploring Shin-Okubo, particularly if you are a fan of Korean pop culture and beauty products. You get an amenity bag daily with slippers, pyjamas, towels, a toothbrush and toothpaste. Handy for those who forgot to bring these items or want to reduce their load of laundry. The capsules are pleasantly spacious and there is a power point to charge your electronics inside. You can't lock your capsules but there is a screen you can pull down if you want privacy. I would highly recommend staying here if you have a JR pass (Shin-Okubo is on the JR Yamanote line very close to Shinjuku, Harajuku and Shibuya) or if you would like to experience a capsule hotel in Tokyo.

nice atmosphere, very clean hotel, proper capsule hostel for solo traveler. one little thing, they have an early check out time and you have to check out and check in every day if you stay more than one night. little bit inconvenience for me tho. but the overall is very good.

I stayed here as part of my travels around Japan with my sister. Having come from our first night in a traditional ryokan, a capsule hotel was also a must-do on our list.This hotel is a 2 minute walk from a train station (shin-okubo) which connects to the busiest local train line in Tokyo (Yamanote line). This hotel is therefore super convenient for the train and hopping around Tokyo Central. There is a 7-11 store just around the corner and you're right at the heart of Korea Town so there's plenty of places to eat and drink.This place is good to meet other travellers but also good if you need a cheap place to stay with a comfortable bed and a hot shower. Each day you can check in from 1pm and you're given a QR code key for your locker, towels, a toothbrush and toothpaste, and some pyjamas and a pair of slippers. The service here is brilliant and the staff speak good English. The place is super clean and mostly very quiet, with amazing views from either window in the relaxation area. Here you can take calls, eat, drink, and go on laptops. You can't smoke anywhere in this building. The lockers are good and have a separate section for your shoes and somewhere to hang your suit if you have one. The showers provide shampoo, conditioner, and soap and are a lovely temperature. There is also a bath on the ladies shower floor, not sure about the mens. When you enter the hotel you do so using the central elevator. The lift on the left of the centre is for men and the other one is for women. Each pod is for one person only. The lockers and pods are on the same floors and men and women have two floors each as well as a showers room. There are plenty of showers, sinks, and toilets. Please be a considerate guest and be as quiet as possible in the pods, turn your phone to silent apart from your alarm and don't take calls in here. The walls between the pods are quite thin and basically its like a novelty hostel. The building is also near to the train line so the pods do shake a bit when the train goes past. Each pod has a privacy blind, a duvet, mattress and a pillow and two small shelves, somewhere to charge your device(s) and an adjustable light. Check out is at 10 every day and you can't get another key card until 1pm. This is for safety reasons and they also have to have time to keep the place clean!This place is well priced and well located.

If you want live capsule hostel experience this place really good option. Everything was clean. I really enjoyed staying there. Also, staffs were very friendly and helpful. Breakfast in a close cafe, but it was good.

A unique hotel experience. Quite comfortable even for someone 6'2". The capsules are quite roomy (I couldn't touch the ceiling laying flat on my back) and was able to lay full length even with the privacy shade down.It can be a little noisy, so earplugs if you're a light sleeper. Also bring something cool to sleep in as it can get a little warm once you pull the privacy shade.

The capsules were very clean and spacious. It is located in koreatown so you will have easy access to many restuarants. The lounge also has a great view of the city. I enjoyed my stay a lot. Thank you 9hours, very cool.

The capsules themselves were very nice, quiet and spacious. We were given pajamas, towels and it felt like a very premium experience. The showers and bathrooms were also very spacious and luxurious. The wifi is also very fast. There was also a complimentary free breakfast ticket for a nearby cafe which was a great bonus.Amazing view of the city as well.

Even though you have booked multiple days you have to checkout every day by 10am and that means you also can’t check back in till 1pm. So even though we’re allowed to leave our stuff in the lockers, we cannot access our lockers between 10 AM and 1 PM. The women’s bathrooms have no hook on the back of the door for a purse or little table to set your stuff on. So you end up having to put all of your stuff on the bathroom floor. One pillow, will not allow you an extra pillow. One plug in the capsule, so if you need to charge multiple things at a time you need to do that on the local floor.

Nice place, very quiet and clean, good experience, a must try for one nightWell located at 15 min walking distance from central Shinjuku. Small space around lockers, specially if you carry on a big suitcase

Great place, good location not far from the touristic spots just 2 min walk from the station,main Street. Very clean and modern. Quiet. Perfect for shorter stays 1-3 nights. Very comfortable capsules (!).

Views from the 8th floor are great. The pictures of the accommodation are accurate. The showers and pods were immaculately clean. The staff were welcoming and always behind the desk if you need them. Would definitely recommend a stay here - great location too!

Nice experience of local living in a tube. The design could be better though. This is located in a great location. The stuff is very friendly, although they speak very basic english so be prepared if you want to communicate with them.

This is our first capsule experience. All together comfy stay but it would be nice to have TV or radio in the capsule, also laundry would be useful on site. The locker area is a bit narrow and is hard to find your clothes if it's busy. Nice staff and superclean place.

Our family came here on our last day of a five day holiday in Japan. Our son had always wanted to experience what a “capsule hotel” stay was like. The experience was wonderful with incredibly clean and modern amenities, comfortable accommodations, great sized lockers, clean showers and lovely provision of slippers, toothbrush, toothpaste and shower items. Would definitely recommend this experience!!

Very cool place to stay. Clean, modern and a truthful experience. It has been a very good experience. In the other hand the room of the capsules is a bit crowded therefore you can easily hear people’s alarms or snores. The bed and pillow where really confortable and bare in mind you will need an adaptor in case you want to charge your phone (no USB port).Overall I totally recommend it one night!

Futuristic, minimalist but efficient capsule hotel close to Shinjuku. The capsules are comfortable and clean, staff is great and English speaking. Right next the yamanote line. Perfect choice to stay on Tokyo!

My brother and I wanted to try the POD lifestyle. This was a much better experience than expected. Everything was very clean, staff was attentive, and sleeping room was very quiet. We were also given an included breakfast at a restaurant next door. Located in a great location. Very glad we tried this out highly recommend.

Family and friends spent a night at Nine Hours Shinjuku-North. First time in the capsule type sleeping arrangement with shared facilities. Quite impressive set up. Nice and clean, convenient location.

The hotel is conveniently next to the station in a clean and modern setting. Nice and friendly staff. The sleeping floor itself is the highlight with its individual sleeping pods! Definitely recommend this one but the light sleeper might want to bring ear plugs...

From someone who lives in little old New Zealand, this captual hotel feels like something from the future. Not to mention the view as well! The cleanliness and organised feel of the hotel is exceptional. The front desk staff are very kind and were speedy with check in and out. I’m travelling with one big back pack and a smaller bag too, both fit in the locker well together! The showers were clean and came with their own shampoo, conditioner and body wash. They pyjamas provided are extremely comfortable as well. The pods themselves were good, I slept deep the whole night. However, you can hear some noises of people scattering around leaving and entering the room. I had an amazing stay though! Will be recommending this to many friends and be returning over and over again!

The hostel is in a very good area, with a lot of things happening and easy to get to most of the great sights in Tokyo since it’s close to the subway station. One stop away is Shinjuku station with loads of connecting subway lines. The hostel is very clean and comfortable! Would definitely stay here again.

A nice budget accommodation. Great location, very clean and helpful staff. English-speaking. Plenty of showers and bathrooms. Mattress and pillow are very firm but ok for a shorter stay. Would stay again.

The capsules are quite spacious, and the futuristic look is quite an experience. The lockers are very spacious, but not for really big suitcases. They give a bad on check-in with some toiletries, towel and pyjama, that was nice. The showers are really good, and the common area is very nice too, some individual space is you need to work on your laptop. The views are incredible, and the location is great, many restaurants around and convenience store just next to it. It was a great experience.But the elevator is a bit annoying. From the room, you can't go straight to the ground floor, you have to always go to reception on level 8, and then take another elevator to the ground floor. It's the same when you come back, you have to go to reception at level 8 and then take another elevator to your floor.

The tubes were clean and the place was nice and Located close to resturants I would definitely stay there again.The showers were located on the seventh floor and it was quiet at night.They give you a bag with a towel slippers and pajamas,everything you need for the night

The 9-hours hotel in the Shinjuku -district is quite spartan, with a cool gimmick. Bring some earplugs for when you're going to sleep, as one guy adjacent to me hit the richter scale with his snoring:)

Enjoyed my stay here, enough space for us to sort out our luggage into locker, clean shower place, soundproofing of the sleeping pod is good.Not recommend for partygoers/those staying more than 1 night as we are required to check out at 10 every morning and re check in again at 1pm.Nonetheless, awesome capsule hotel stay experience.

Always enjoy my time at these places, they are very simple, but still very comfortable and welcoming.I'm 6"4 tall and still have ample room to move around. Can't recommend these enough. Do try them all! They are scattered across the city.

Great living environment, a good attempt at maintaining a level of privacy. Everything you need are there for you, I love the simplicity of the designs and there is no excessive use of things you don’t need. I do wish luggage spaces would be bigger and the travel between luggage and washroom is tedious to do.

Friendly and helpfull staff. Extremely clean. Just a must do experience. Had a good sleep!Perfect location near trainstation.Don't forget to take your adaptor to charge your mobile in the pod, can't charge it on USB.

I had heard of capsule hotels through the travel channel. I found them to be fascinating - when I came to Japan my partner and I decided we wanted to spend our last night (training up from Hiroshima) before flying out. It was easy to find on a bustling street just north of shinjuku. It was a chaotic area which made the quiet of the hotel very distinct. Check in was easy and everything was straightforward. The showers were lovely, and the revised sleepwear was comfortable! My only small note is that it is a bit stuffy in the capsules. It is sometimes loud, but that is to be expected. All the other guests were completely respectful and tried to be quiet. I would stay again!

Generally a good experience. Situated in a nice location (about 10-15 mins walk from Shinjuku, although this depends on walking speed)The atmosphere and decor is simple, modern, and clean, and the capsules are reasonably spacious and comfortable. I slept quite well with minimal disturbances (although I’m a fairly heavy sleeper). Cons are the amount of space in the locker rooms (a person rearranging their luggage tends to block the entire walkway) and towel rental (this is only 100 yen but is kind of annoying).Would book again

Nice facilities, awsome loungeview at 8 floor, individual showerfacilities, clean and Nice. You get all you need for a night, towels, pj, toothbrush and slippers. Genious consept. All in all, very good!

I got into Tokyo pretty early and instead of trying to find a place to lock up my stuff and kill time before check in for my hotel, I popped in here to take a quick nap and recharge.Shinjuku North location is conveniently located right by the train station and check in was quick, but note that you do need to book things online first and it takes about 10 min for the booking to register in their system.Pods are actually pretty spacious and comfortable. I was worried for a bit because I can get a bit claustrophobic, but no issues here!

Clean and tidy capsule. Convenient location. Close to Korean shops and restaurants. Would have preferred some additional amenities but it looks like a great place for students or business visitors. Simple and clean common place.

Very clean, simple and chic capsule hotel. Smack in the middle of Shinjuku North for shops, Korean restaurants and close to the train station (100m). We enjoyed our stay. Other guests were also very courteous re use of showers, common areas and pod area. Great view of Tokyo too!

The pods have plenty of space, the showers and bathrooms are top notch, beautiful lobby with a wonderful view and workplaces, and the best part; it's located in the heart of Shinjuku! The tram station is a block away and is very convenient if you wanna go for sightseeing!By the time I arrived here I made plenty of new contacts from all around the world! If you like being social and meeting people and travel, this is definetly the place!PS; They hand you out uniform-looking pajamas, giving you a serious Maze Runner feel to the place! Especially with all the modern and minimalistic interior!

As someone who was new to the idea of a "capsule hotel," 9 Hours turns the mystique of the capsule hotel and turns it into a real experience. The minute you step foot into the atrium, you are transported to the future. The staff are incredibly friendly, the space supremely clean, and the accommodations hyper futuristic. The capsules themselves are like little space ships and are spacious and comfortable. The daily check in/check out requirements make multi-day stays a bit annoying, and the pods could use more than 1 outlet which is the only reason this review is a 4 instead of a 5. Highly recommend.

review_body: The people who work in the reception need to be able to communicate the rules properly. We went to the reception before 10am and asked several times if it was ok to come back after breakfast to take a shower and use our lockers. This was not going to be a problem. When we got back 10.30 we were told that we could neither use our lockers or the showers. Confusing. After a discussion with another person who worked there, we finally got to take a shower.

Best hostel experience I've had. Simple place but modern and they supply you with what you need: towels, pyjamas and a locker. The ambience is set at a level which keeps everyone quiet and respectful of others. Free Wi-Fi and power socket and covers in your pod. The only downside is you have to check in and check out each day (but you can keep your stuff in your locker), having to pay each day and get new pyjamas and towels. This means leaving the rooms/locker area/washrooms between 10am and 1pm.

You need to get used to the system. It is a clean place and bathroom facilities are clean and comfortable but you need to plan how to make use of themConsidering that you need to go up and down the floors and have the luggage not comfortable to reach

This is a must do for Tokyo. The whole facility, from the incredible 8th floor view, to the otherworldly toilets, was extremely slick. The capsles themselves were cozy and well temperature control led.

Nine Hours Shinjuku-North is conveniently located a few meters away from the Shin-Okubo Metro Station (no elevator/escalator). The area around Nine Hours can get really busy during the day but it was peaceful inside the hotel. The front desk and common area is at the 8th floor. The Women's lockers/sleeping pods/toilets are on the 5th to 6th floor while shower rooms and other toilet cubicles are on the 7th floor. I stayed for 3 nights to try it out. Check in is at 1PM and required daily check out at 10AM. Although daily check out before 10AM is required, luggage can be left stored in the same locker when staying for more than 1 night. The front desk officer will give you another card with QR everyday when you check in and a mesh bag of amenities: pajama, slippers, towels, and toothbrush. Shampoo, conditioner, and body wash are available inside each shower cubicle. Hair dryer and hand/facial tissues available near the sink in the middle. Sleeping pods are in another room. The sleeping pod is roomy with one electrical outlet inside. I felt hot inside but I had a handheld fan with me so it was all good.Overall, it was a good experience.

Unique and unforgettable experience. The staff is very polite and friendly. The cleanliness of the washrooms, bathrooms and pod is extremely good. A must have experience when in Tokyo. Location - centrally located near to a public transport hub and easily accessible to reach all Tokyo attractions.

9 Hours is conceptually brilliant! it's the future of hotels w/ its minimalist aesthetic and super-friendly staff. You'll feel as if you're part of the Starship Enterprise in your pyjamas (daily you'll be given fresh pyjamas, towels, toothbrush/paste). The pods are very comfy and minutes away from the Yamanote Line. Highly recommended.

Had a great stay, very clean and spacious. We felt very safe here. We really loved the pods, they where perfect for what we needed. The view from the sitting area is fantastic and you are close to many restaurants and karaoke bars.

My stay at this capsule hotel was beyond my expectations. The simplistic and minimalistic aesthetic is breathtaking. Service is top knotch with easy check in and check out. The way the capsule hotel operates is very efficient and effective. The living quarters was also bigger and more comfortable than imagined. Air conditioning was sufficiently cooled throughout the building and in the capsule being on the bottom capsule. The locker system is very smart and effective. Washrooms are also mind blowing and very clean. The toilets are amazing. From the lounge to the shower floor to the living quarters every detail is clean, refined, and well thought out. Early luggage drop off before check in is also very convenient. I would definitely stay again another time. Thank you so much Nine hours for a wonderful stay!

The stay was amazing. The staff was very accommodating and it was an awesome experience. Upon check in you receive a bag with amenities for your stay such as towels, toothbrush, slippers and pyjamas. The sleeping pods were very futuristic and quite spacious. I recommend it for the experience and for excellent value for the money.

The stay at the place is amazing with the cool bedding area and overall clean and relaxing interior decoration. Many amenities were provided to me for a very relax and easy stay. It was a wonderful experience and I will definitely come back again in future visit to Japan.

Staying at this capsule hotel was an amazing experience! I was scared the sleeping pod would be tight and make me feel claustrophobic, but there was plenty of space and looked so nice! It was a little bit hot in the pod for my liking, but once I fell asleep it was no problem. I also noticed that the walls were not sound proof, but it didn't bother me. Everything was so clean and aesthetically pleasing. The toilet seats automatically flip open when you enter the washroom which amazed me. The service was wonderful as well. There is a lounge area which is very spacious and also very relaxing. I would definitely recommend.

9 Hours in Shinjuku was a one of a kind experience. It feels very futuristic in its simplistic look and decor, yet still relaxing and comfortable. The staff is very friendly and the hotel provides you with a small bag of amenities should you be too lazy to unpack your own after putting it away in your own QR code locker. As for my rest, I found the sleeping pods were very comfortable and spacious, so no claustrophobia from me. I came with a group of 3 women and 2 men, and although floor arrangements are separated into genders, the reception floor also doubles as a lounge which was great for us to meet up. Not to mention the view from the 8th floor of the northern Shinjuku area was stunning. Overall I had a charming experience and I would highly recommend for a one night stay.

So first off, the capsule hotel is really a unique experience. When you first step in it looks really cool, however for myself I wish I’d have left after the first 5 minutes. The capsules seem to amplify the noise by there shape and position, also the fact that they are plastic probably doesn’t help. It honestly felt like staying in a dormitory with 100 roommates. For some reason the floor got really busy around midnight with somebody coming in or leaving every 5 minutes. I’m not sure if it’s the fact that you can hear everything so well or that I was particularly unlucky with my roommates for the night, but at 2 am I had to ask someone to turn to sound of on their phone as they were playing a game. Of course the hotel is not at fault for the behavior of its guests, but it seems to me that they attract certain behavior by allowing 24h check in and by not making the capsules noise proof. Other than the pair of pajamas you get and the capsule itself the hotel offers nothing special, the capsules are not equipped with anything special and the common space has nothing that makes you want to hang out there (which is probably why people are playing games in their pods) breakfast is at a nearby diner. All in all the experience is cool but I’ll definitely never stay at 9h again.O they also give a gift to anyone who shows them they leave a review on TripAdvisor, so expect reviews to be biased.

This is a good place to sleep. If you are by yourself, this place is good. It's not sound proof. If you're a big snorer or there are other people that snore, you can hear everything. One thing I did not like is that you need to check out every day by 10am. You can go back to your capsule at 1pm. I guess they don't want you to be in there while they clean up. You can keep your things in the locker that they provide you with if you're staying for multiple nights. Hotel is located in Korean Town. So good food is all around.

Amazing stay! will come back always. it was so clean and so futuristic, literally instagram worthy and worth every penny. We stayed for one night and wanted to immediately stay for longer! the experience is a MUST if in Japan.

Overall a great experience, showers and locker area are very clean and sleeping room was cool and quiet. Closest station is a short 200m walk away and a supermarket is located also just a block away. Free fast wi-fi available throughout the building. Highly recommended.

I stayed at the capsule just to try it (when in Japan!!!) and i was not disappointed! really amazing experience, really clean facilities and nice people who work there. i slept so well, bed was so comfy and for the price i will 1000% be staying here again!!! what an experience!!!

This 9hours capsule hotel in Shinjuku-North is modern, clean and gives you a smooth, no-nonsense travel experience. Great value for money. You just gotto love the capsule concept, consider it an upscale hostel with more privacy ;)

Have stayed at this hotel twice and will be back. I looked everywhere for cheap accommodation in the Shinjuku area and this was the best. Has all amenities, secure luggage storage, friendly staff and is only a two minute walk from the train station. There’s always plenty of hot water and room for my luggage. Will be back.

Facility is clean and very near the shopping area and major train stations. Whats best is very near Don Quijote, Ichiran, Ramen Nagi and the famous Gracery Hotel with Godzilla Head. Totally Instagramable!! Highly recommended!

Nice place and convenient we will come back and return to this place, we will recommend this place to our friends in manila philippines.worth value and worth money for travellers like us, please try this place in shinjuku

This is the least but best you can get from a hotel: a perfect bed and shower. Most comfortable bed and best shower I have ever experienced in hotels, although the downsides are no door for your spacious capsule so people might not be the most considerate at all times. Also I missed my partner who was staying in male dormitory :)) also I personally prefer to sleep in a place where there is a small window BUT this is capsule hotel and it’s really good for what it is. Reasonable pricing and good access around.

This is my second trip to Japan and I did try quite a few different capsule hotels. This one is still my favourite! The super stylish concept of the 9 hours brand is great, the place always clean and the check-in/check-out is smooth. I tried the Akasaka branch too, but Shinjuku North is way better: more space, bigger lockers, more showers and a beautiful lobby with amazing Skyline views of Tokyo. I love to work in the little cubicles, that also double as a sort of coworking space.Can totally recommend!

This was my first time at a capsule-style hotel,would definitely stay here again. The hotel included everything you need for a night: toothbrush and paste, plush towels, slippers, even pajamas. The entire place is very clean and updated. There is a common area with floor to ceiling windows where you can eat or just look at the city scape. Capsule sleeping pods provide a decent amount of privacy. My only complaint is that the airflow in the capsule is minimal. In the middle of the night the air felt sort of stale. I had to open up the privacy shade and sleep with my pod open for ventilation.

I would recommend this hotel to people who are traveling to Tokyo on a budget. It is affordable and very clean. The hotel provides pjs and slippers for you to wear. They also provide towels, tooth brush and soap, shampoo, and conditioner for the shower. The showers are large and private. They're clean too. The sleeping room is dark and quiet. There are no doors on the pods though - only a curtain that comes down to cover your pod door so you have privacy. I suggest bringing ear plugs because sometimes guests bring their large roll on suitcases into the sleeping quarters which can wake you up. There are lockers that you can keep your stuff in though. The pod has a light and plug to charge your phone in it. The bed is very comfortable and the blanket is warm. I think it is a cool experience to stay at a hotel like this and suggest you try it out when in Japan! The front desk staff were friendly and spoke some English. The hotel is located a block from the JR train station.

review_body: My wife and I stayed here for one night more for the experience than for any other reason. The "hotel" is extremely clean and well organised and gave a good first impression. On arrival you are issued a card for access to your locker which houses a bag containing pyjamas, slippers, towel, tooth brush and tooth paste (everything you could need). The lockers are massive and easily fit 2 large backpacks with space to spare (This was one of our concerns before arriving). The common room is clean and tidy and has space for you to charge electronics or work on a laptop, it also has a nice view of Shinjuku. From the reception / common area you go down either the male or female lift to get to the segregated sleeping and washing areas. The washing areas have around (and this is a guess) 12 showers and 10 toilets with basins and mirrors down the center, and at no point were there any queues with what looked like a full house. The sleeping area is very space age and looked great in my eyes. The beds are large enough that you can easily sit up and move around and they have charging points a couple of small shelves and a pull down blind. I got a good night's sleep but was awoken early morning by someone nearby having a bad dream and making some strange noises, but other than that it was reasonably quiet to say how many people were in the room together. Overall it was a good experience and at a good price so i would recommend it to anyone who is used to sleeping in hostels / refuges / bunk rooms etc.

It was in my list for Japan to experience while here.Reception in 8th floorSeparate elevators to male and female floors. Keycard to locker, which holds a bag with towels, slippers, PJ’s and toothbrush. Shower clean and large enough to put your stuff out and get changed.Location: great near stationJoined area: great views, sit area you can relax.Breakfast is not in same location but a 5’ walkIf you stay more than 1 night you will daily have to check out and in

Bergen op Zoom, The Netherlands

review_body: Spent two nights at the this capsule hotel. Immaculately clean. Friendly helpful staff. Excellent location 5 minutes from the JR Yamanote line, easy transfer from Haneda airport and great for Shinjuku and Shibuya.Capsule was bigger than it looks in pictures, mattress firm partner thought it was too warm I was happy with the temperature. Would I stay again yes , however for no more than.2 nights as there is no natural light until you go to reception area, which is large and airy.

Stayed here 2 night for some reason this place gets so busy and noisy at about 12 o'clock at night when people are trying to sleep . The sleep pods door does say please be quiet but the people staying are doing everything but that of you need sleep anywhere 1pm till 8pm it's great after that good lunch

We stayed at 9Hrs Shinjuku for a night just to experience staying at a capsule hotel, and we were not at all disappointed.I understand that this place opened in March 2019 for the business, so quite new and fresh looking. We liked the facilities, including shower, washrooms, big locker place and sleeping pod. The kit provided by 9Hrs was adequate, and the premises clean and tidy. One issue we faced was absence of temperature control for individual pods, which bothered few of us. Location was great, near to train station and convenience stores and restaurants nearby. Staff was very helpful as well. Most helpful thing here was they allowed us to keep our bags after check-out as we were heading for sight-seen before we check-in into another hotel. One peculiar thing to remember is that you don't get access to pods from 10am to 1pm, as its closed for cleaning.Apart from few peculiarities, we enjoyed our experience very much and recommend the place for a night max for families.

Loved it. It was perfect for a couple of nights. The capsule hotel is part of the Tokyo experience. It was super clean and the staff very friendly. The location is perfect. I would recommend it to everyone.

My first time at a capsule hotel. I enjoyed the overall concept. Basic amenities provided and a no fuss experience with checking in and storing your valuables. My only suggestion is to please include earplugs in the amenities bag. I lost mine on the night of my stay here, and all it took was a group of drunk idiots to wake my entire floor up at 3:30AM.

Everything is clinically kept in white and it feels a bit like being in a hospital, but the whole place is clean and functional. Male and female dorms are on separate floors, which you reach using different elevators. After your check-in you will first store your luggage in lockers and change into indoor clothes and slippers that you will find there. The capsules are simple but will do as a bed for a night or two. If you stay longer than one night you have to check out in the morning and remove your things from the capsule for cleaning, but you can keep the locker. 9 hours hostels are some of the cheaper accommodation options in Japan and still pretty expensive considering that you share space with around 30 other persons and despite can hear almost every single noise they make. If you have a light sleep, use earplugs!

This was my first experience in a capsule hotel and all my negative ideas of it were wrong! This was comfier, cleaner and nicer than most of the dorms I've tried in Japan.They have compartmentalized each floor - reception, shower rooms, beds. Beds are divided into 2 floors - one for the men and the other for the women. Lockers were big enough to store my large luggage and hang a coat.Each day you have to check-out but it's merely just leaving off your QR code badge so that your room can be cleaned everyday.I had thoughts that staying in capsules will be claustrophobic but it was very spacious inside. You could hear few movements from people but it didn't really bother me from falling asleep.

Nice, clean capsule hotel, very close to shin-okubo station. Pods are very clean and comfortable, there is an electric plug in each pod, which makes it very convenient. Prices are ok for Tokyo. Close to several combinis and Korean restaurants.

The staff here were very helpful, everyone I spoke to had good English, I asked for the temperature in my dorm to be lowered a little and they immediately adjusted it. The pods were more spacious than some I've stayed in previously. Modern, spotless, good price, easy to find, 15-20 minute walk to the central Shinjuku area, big lockers for your belongings, and a nice view of the city from the lounge area. I had a very good night's sleep here. One negative point however is that we had to check out every day and leave our luggage at reception, despite being booked in for two nights.

We enjoyed staying in this place. Well organised with everything a travellers could need. Very quiet in the sleeping area. Enough space in a capsule to feel comfortable. Good location, situated at a very busy street, with plenty of shops and bars.

Enjoyed the views and atmosphere in the office space, good showers, capsule is clean etc and there is good storage space in the lockers. Unfortunately it was downhill from there as an individual in the dorm decided to make phone calls in his pod most of the night. Even after trying to ask him to be quiet he just carried on. I know it's not the fault of the venue however I can imagine it's a common problem! The pods are not very sound proof at all and can get very warm!

Not only is this an incredibly unique accommodation experience but a genuinely fantastic place to stay! Great location - 2 minute walk from JR station Shin Okubo and about a 10 minute walk from central Shinjuku. The area is known as Korea Town with many great restaurants and shops on your doorstep. It feels like a super authentic area, with hardly any western tourists.The hotel itself is spotless, modern and well designed. Upon check in you’re assigned a capsule number, locker, slippers, pyjamas and towel. If you’re staying multiple days you must check out each day, but don’t worry your capsule and locker stays the same throughout your stay, but you can not access them from 10am-1pm while the staff are cleaning the areas. Showers are on a different floor to your capsule, but they are spacious, clean and fully stocked with toiletries.There’s probably 50+ capsule in each dorm room so expect a bit of noise/snoring. Just remember your earplugs and sleeping mask if you’re a light sleeper.Overall a fantastic stay and I’d recommend it to everyone!

Very comfortable and convenient place to stay. Big common areas make it easy to work, visit or read.Check in was quick and the staff was helpful. All areas were perfectly clean.Sleeping area was quiet and comfortable. Great overnight option

I had wanted to stay at a 'capsule' hotel since I first saw them in a magazine as a child. I liked the idea and Nine Hours was the modern (you might even use "space age") ideal choice for me. I was bold and booked it following our 14 hour flight, and maybe the jet lag had something to do with it, but I slept incredibly well! The mattress is very thin which made it firm, but that works well for me. I was concerned it would be too hot, but the temp was perfect. This is obviously not a place to hang out-- you're there to shower and sleep. Despite the communal nature of these types of hotels, the toilets were in private rooms and the bath/showers were in private rooms. The only time you really needed to see you bunk mates was when using the row of sinks.It's modern, minimalist design at its finest. It's the kind of design I really appreciate, though I understand many wouldn't. But I wonder if something like it would work in the States for more open-minded travelers? It saves money because it saves space/resources. It's more hotel than hostel. And as I found out, it's more than a bucket list experience, it's a straight-up comfortable night of sleep!

It is my second time staying there. I spend my last night coming from the Japanese alps before flying off in late afternoon from Narita.The location is convenient close to many eateries, bars and shops - ideal to kill a few hours before getting in the plane.There is one metro station that brings you to Shinjuku or Tokyo station.As long as you set up the right expectations you will enjoy.The whole process of checking in is highly efficient. The pod is comfy and well heated. The common area is quite pleasant, withoffice space, very well heated too.The whole place, pod and common areas offer good and fast wifi connection.The bathroom, locker room and pods are very clean and well maintained.I could sleep well thanks to my noise canceling headset. My first time I did not have those and did not feel as much rested. The light pollution is not as potent as the noise, but in case it is good to have a mask with you.Overall the place offers a good value option. They keep it simple and deliver on it.

I had a great stay st the 9hr in Shinjuku- the facilities were clean, checkin was really simple, the price was really great. there are private showers and bathrooms and you get a private locker and the capsules have shades that pull down for privacy- i definitely recommend for a short stay - they had common lounge on the check in floor so there is workspace if needed. the staff spoke some english was very friendly and welcoming to tourists. 5 stars!!!

Stayed here for three nights because I wanted to check out the hype was all about. This capsule hotel was in an excellent location near the train station, plenty of Korean restaurants (high concentration of Korean fast food and restaurants) and a short walked to Shinjuku central. The pods were clean, spacious, warm and cozy. Bathrooms were very clean and each toilet was separate and private. Will stay again and met my expectations.

Nice place to stay when you don’t need a whole lot. I didn’t get in until midnight , didn’t book online and was going to cost me like 8000yen so I stood their and booked for the far cheaper rate. So if you see a cheaper rate book it so you have it set.Showers were very clean, pod was very clean . A little on the warm side but not bad. Charger port in your pod.And they have a big locker to store all your stuff in.

It looks like a laboratory.Fascinating experience.The capsule its bigger than it looks.All is clean.They give you sleepers, pijamas, towels, brushtooth.I booked through booking and it said it included breakfast, but there werent any breakfast. So booking was wrong.Check in 13, check out 10 am.You have a plug inside the capsule

location- 3/5 it is near the jr shinjuku station but is more or less 1km walk to the nearest metro station. since it is in the koreantown area, there is a lot of restuarants, convenient stores and beauty/pharmacy stores. ambiance- 5/5 the lobby is located on the top floor as well as the common area where you can eat. the capsule pods and lockers are on the same floor but the bathroom is on a different floor. there is a separate elevators for the male and female areas. cleanliness- 5/5 upon checked in, they will provide you a bag with pajamas, towels, slipper and toothbrush. the capsule pods are being kept clean everyday. the bathroom are spacious and very neat. service- 4/5 some staff are able to converse in simple english however when i inquired on how to get to the subway they were not able to provide accurate instructionsactivities- 2/5 since it is really for backpackers, there is limited activity although they provide a spacious common area for eating etc

I stayed at Nine Hours Shinjuku for five days in mid-December and had a great experience.Location: 9h is located in the middle of Tokyo's Koreatown, about a 3-minute walk away from Shin Okubo station. There are a lot of stores selling kpop merchandise, korean beauty products, and Korean restaurants nearby. Amenities: Everything is very new and very clean. When you check in every day, they hand you a new toiletries bag that has a bath towel, a face towel, a pair of slippers, a toothbrush set and a set of pajamas. There is a bottle of bath soap, shampoo and conditioner in each shower room. The shower rooms themselves are very spacious. Hair dryers are offered. Capsule: The capsule did not feel claustrophobic to me, though the temperature inside was considerably higher than the temperature outside, so if you are easily overheated, I would suggest bringing some lighter clothing to sleep in. There is also only one single outlet inside the capsule. Since one floor has 52 capsules which are all linked together, you can feel/hear quite clearly when people come in and out. Females and males are put on separate floors and use different elevators to access these floors. Locker: Since you do not get to put your things inside the capsule during the day, even if you are staying for multiple days, they offer a locker to put your luggage in. It is locked with a paper key card that has a QR code on it. I had a 28 inch suitcase and it fit okay. Service: You can store your suitcase here after you check out.All in all, it was a very enjoyable stay. Though I had to check in and check out every single day, the process was usually quite fast.

The main reason why I decided to stay in Nine Hours is because I wanted to experience staying in a capsule hotel. Its one of the experiences I wont pass up in Tokyo.The location of this capsule hotel is very central in Tokyo. Its one minute stop from SHinjuku station. As you exit the only exit way from the station to turn right go towards the direction of the railway bridge and on your right you will see 7 eleven. The entrance to the hotel is right after the 7-11 store.You can only use one lift going up to the 8th floor where the reception desk is located. As you enter the 8th floor, the reception desk will e right infront of you .A wall separates the reception desk and the main lobby where there is a long table, individual booths and a viewing deck of a nice view of the Shinjuku area.Once you check in they will give you a black net bag containing two towels, a black slipper, a pajama set and a toothbrush.They will also give you a card where there is a bar code you will swipe in your locker to open the locker. You have to return all that except for the slippers and toothbrush to the reception desk when you check out the next day,Everyone is expected to check out everyday before 10 am.There are no facilities for dining so you can buy food outside and eat it in the lobby. U cannot consume food inside your capsule.There is a separate floor for women (5th and 6th floor) shared showers are on the 7th floor. Each floor has toilets and wash basins.The capsules are actually quite spacious. I am 5'2 and I can sit up properly inside and my feet barely touches the privacy screen that you can put down at night.The hotel is located in Korean town and if you are adventurous enough you can actually walk to Shinjuku main station from the hotel.When I checked in on the first day the receptionist was very nice and friendly but on my second night the girl who checked me in was grumpy and showed her displeasure when I came back to tell her that my locker has another bag inside(they told me I can use the same locker on my second night).If you want to stay in an affordable place and near the tourist area, try to stay in this place. Its worth at least one night stay.

The location is very convenient and easy to find. This being said, it’s north of Shinjuku and more centrally located in Korea town, which was interesting to see, though at night the area dies. Many restaurants and bars were closed by midnight, so if you’re looking to party this won’t be the spot.In terms of the hotel/capsules, this was a great experience! The facilities are clean and orderly. The staff was very friendly and able to communicate in English. The capsules were comfortable and surprisingly spacious. Lastly, and probably the best part, breakfast is included just down the street at Gusto, which is a solid Japanese diner-style spot. Overall, I definitely recommend this spot!

PositivesGreat location. The capsules are quiet. Clean facilities. Enough showers. Enough room to move around. A great view from the common room.Negatives Extra blankets were not provided as I was a bit cold so slept in my fleece.

The conditions and standards in this hotel are very good: beds are comfortable, staff is very nice and helping, very clean hotel, large capsules, great common room with a great view of Shinjuku area, very central, and reasonable prices.But there is one rule they have you should know before booking there: You have to do a check out every day at 10:00 am, even if you're booked for more than one night. You check out at 10:00 am every day, and You re-check in later starting from 13:00. And, between 10:00-13:00, You're allowed only to use the common room.which means: if You're a party animal or a night person, it's not recommended for you to go to this hotel.

Stayed one night for the novelty. What really made the experience was the beautiful modern lobby with great views and the friendly staff. You are greeted with a bag that includes slippers, a robe and tooth brush and tooth paste, then you head to the lockers to place your bags, shower, and hit the capsule. Only complaint was the mold growing on the ceiling in the women's bathroom. That was very off putting. Otherwise it is a nicely designed space. My travel companion and I were the only ones in the dorm when we went to bed around 10pm by 4am it was completely full. While folks tried to be respectful and quiet it certainly doesn't hurt to bring ear plugs.

I stayed here with my other friends. the location is very strategic, you can find lots of place to eat, train station and shopping area by walking distance. The room itself is quite nice, I thought it will be smaller but apparently not. One of my friend was worried because she has claustrophobic but in the end she has no problem at all. They provide you towel, face towel, tooth brush, and pajamas to use! The only thing that bothered me is the locker. the space is quite small so it is quite a challenge to arrange your luggage on your locker area but you can manage by finding an empty space nearby! :)

I really like this capsule hotel mentality and they are doing the best with all facilities. Just perfect. You should stay there and enjoy Tokyo. Location, staff, facilities... perfect! In addition they are very helpful in order to make you relax.

I stayed here for 4 nights. I visited Tokyo alone and wanted something cheap. I found the capsule to be very comfortable. For the most part guests inside the sleeping room respected other guests and remained quiet while inside. Very clean bathrooms. Great location near subway. Lots of places to eat/shop nearby.

I'm currently staying at Nine Hours and wish I had booked another hostel. I have stayed at hostels around tokyo for cheaper and this is the worst hostel I have stayed at by far. The pods have uncomfortable beds and are situated in noisy rooms that echo with sound. Each pod room is cramped with dozens of beds. There are way too many people going in and out at all hours of the night. The pod doors are flimsy and let every sound in. There are also no windows or natural light in the rooms so good luck if you feel claustrophobic. To make matters worse you have to check out and check back in every day of your stay, meaning you have to pack and unpack every single day. This is such a pain and waste of time. And the ONE elevator that takes you to your room is inconvenient and takes forever. Plus the whole hostel is very poorly ventilated and they play obnoxious elevator music everywhere, making it impossible to get work done or find a peaceful place to relax. NEVER AGAIN. I CAN'T WAIT TO GET OUT OF HERE.

We only stayed one night, so it was fine. The pods are comfortable and only annoying when people chat outside. You only have a roll down screen to shield you. People are mostly reapectful, so it is very quiet, but you do hear everything. To be honest, I expected something more high tech. There was only 1 plug—not even a USB outlet (in this day and age!) So couldn’t charge my phone, which was annoying. There’s literally nothing but 1 light, 1 plug, 1 pillow and 1 comforter. There is no temperature control, which was missed. I felt too warm and stifled in my pod. I've seen that this is a common complaint. The common areas are very clean. Nice showers with good water pressure. The WiFi is good when it works. It stopped every now and then. This hotel is located in a great part of Tokyo, Koreatown. So loads of restaurants, street food, and shops. Really fun! You have to check out every day at 10 a.m., which could be annoying if you stay long. A fun experience for about £49 ($63) a night. It should be slightly cheaper, in my opinion, as it is pretty minimalist. We had 4 capsules, which cost £196 ($252). Avoid booking through Agoda.com. Confusing website and terrible customer service if you have problems with the booking. I've booked through Expedia, TripAdvisor, and Booking.com, and never had such problems.

Location is easy to find, in the middle of Tokyo's Korean Town, Shin-Okubo.Provides good amenities : towels, pajamas, tooth brush, soap.We had a good night sleep here. There are a lots of shops and food around the hotel.

This was my first time staying at a capsule hotel and I loved it! Clean and quiet, and I was pleasantly surprised by the size of the capsules (I’m 5’10” and had plenty of space, and my 6’3” husband felt the same). They provide PJs, slippers, towels, and even toothbrushes! The location was great, about a 4 min walk from the nearest JR station and surrounded by a ton of restaurants. For the price and convenience and I would definitely stay here again.

We landed late and had an early train to meet in the morning, so a capsule hotel was a cheap and obvious option for us. Check in is 24hr and simple. It's really close to Shin Okubo Station - one stop up from Shinjuku Station (about 20min walk) and the place was super clean and modern. It's right in the middle of Korea town, and there are loads of food options in the immediate vicinity.The pods are surprisingly large - not claustrophobic at all. Mattresses are firm but comfy. Pillow's are a little weird, but not unusable. Bathrooms are well equipped, private and squeaky clean. I was expecting to be able to plug a usb cord into the console to charge my phone, but the outlet in the pod was a normal Japanese wall plug - so take your whole charger and adaptor in with you. There was nowhere to open a suitcase in the locker room, so you have to do all your organising on the floor in everybody's way. Also, the pyjamas are definitely not one size fits all westerners. The pods are no more soundproof than a dormitory, but are more private. A/C is centrally controlled and the doona provided was way too hot, but aren't they always in every hotel?Would definitely stay again.

I had stayed at two Nine Hours branches in the same trip to Tokyo and this was the better one. Both were clean and well-maintained to their usual standards. There were no vending machine or water fountain in the property. But since it's located in Korean town near Shin-Okubo Station it's surrounded by many shops, convenience stores, and restaurants. The property has 3 elevators and only one of them allows access from street level to the 8th floor where the reception and the lounge are. Separate elevators connect to male and female floors from the 8th floor, meaning you have to connect on the 8th floor everytime you return to your pod (room) from outside. Some consider this an inconvenience, some consider this added security. Lockers and restrooms are on the same floor as your pods. My 29" suitcase was able to fit into the locker which was a huge plus. Towels, toothbrush, pajamas, and slippers were provided. The water pressure of the showers was extremely good. However, the showers were not on the same floor as the pods which I did find inconvenient. The pods were fitted with light switches and a power outlet. It was a little stiff and warm especially after showering. Nobody talked or played music in the sleeping area but I was woken up by other people's alarms in the morning. All in all a very nice experience and I would definitely stay again.

A capsule hotel is a must have experience. It is very comfortable and the hotel supplies everything you need for a short stay. The staff was very helpful and kind. There are different floors for men and women and access is supervised by help desk what provided a sense of high security. Isolation from noise within the capsule was not so good but talking is prohibited.

Really cool place to stay for a few nights in a convenient location (Korean area one station north of Shinjuku). It was clean and the staff were lovely. Capsules were comfortable and had a light/charging point. Shared showers/toilets were good, price very was reasonable for Tokyo and included a tasty breakfast at a cafe down the road. The only thing that we disliked was the daily checkout at 10am and re-check-in after 1pm which was really inconvenient as you couldn't access your locker, the bathrooms etc or if you'd had a few drinks the night before you couldn't sleep in if needed. General loud snorers and people in the sleeping room but nothing unexpected. Good for a night or two, we recommend it.

9hours was very clean and well-kept. Staff was friendly and spoke good English. It was easy to communicate with them to let them know that my key card wasn't working, whereas I had extreme difficulty letting staff know the same problem at another hotel.Was a bit expensive considering the lack of amenities - there wasn't even a vending machine. I stayed in capsule hotels in Akihabara for $15-20 cheaper that had TVs in the cap, better cap charging stations, and better lounges.

Well I stayed in 9 hours Kyoto 9-10 years back. Concept is still cool but a few things.1. The number of inconsiderate guests has risen (surely being quiet in the sleeping area isn’t that hard to enforce and make clear on check in?) including a guy who thought it was acceptable to bring what I can only describe as all the plastic bags in Tokyo into the area, imagine that noise at 2am!!! 2. The showers etc are clean but renovations are needed with dripping and mouldy air inlets at high level in the shower communal areas, suggests poor maintenance. 3. Waste - surely its time to considered the need to hand out plastic toothbrushes, people tend to travel with their own or at least make them optional, more plastic waste being generated for no reason.4. Where are the pod alarm clocks now, instead we have phone alarms starting from 3:30am on the half hour and those same inconsiderate guests seem to then sleep through said alarm.My second and last time in a pod for sure, had a few hours of broken sleep...9 hours it’s time to rethink the design, the fun factor will only work for a while. Rant over as I’m tired and watching the sun come up.

If you're keen to try a capsule hotel, then this is a great option. It is very modern and stylish, and has all you need for a good night's sleep. The location is quite a walk from the nearest metro station, and pretty far from Shinjuku station, so it is not the easiest to get to and from with heavy suitcases.
