Blake R
Cape Town Central, South Africa

review_body: Stayed here for two night. This is my first experience staying at a capsule hotel and it's quite pleasant. I was rather concerned that I might be a bit suffocated sleeping in such a small space only to find out the capsule was quite spacious and comfortable. The divided male and female guests into two different capsule sections as well as different bathroom sections which is nice. Everything is clean and cozy,loved the lounge area, and the staff members are nice, and speak pretty good English. The only downside that we need to check in and out everyday even though we booked for multiple days, which can be a bit of a hassle but that's probably how most capsule hotels are being run. Location is good, at the heart of Shinjuku. Recommended for solo travelers if you want an affordable and practical stay in Tokyo.

Something that always fascinated me about Japan were capsule hotels, so during my time in Tokyo, I thought it would be cool to try one out and I had a great time.It’s located in a modern building with a sleek basic design which is somehow charming with a main lobby and then men and women separate dorms and shower rooms. You are given pyjamas which are comfy, a toothbrush, tickets for breakfast at a local cafe and a sizeable locker to put your things in.If you are worried about the capsule pods themselves, don’t be worried, I’m quite a tall person and was able to fit inside with enough room to extend my legs. Inside the pod is a curtain for some privacy, a charging socket, pillow, duvet and mattress. During the nights I was there everyone was quiet and I got to sleep easy, sometimes people set alarms on their phones which do wake you up, but I can resleep fine.All in all, I loved the place and would happily go back!

My friend and I arrived into Tokyo very early in the morning and headed to the 9 Hours. We wanted to leave our bags at the hotel knowing that we may not be able to check in yet. Upon arrival before I could even get a word out to reception, the receptionist very rudely said “check in is not I’ll 1”. He continued to be rude as we sorted our selfs and bags out. He also seemed to be very rude to his co-worker. This left a bitter taste for us and we were not looking forward to checking in or staying there. As for the capsule hotel itself it very interesting and would recommended staying there. Very clean and awesome experience just beware of the ONE staff member who ruined it for us.

The design is cool, its clean and it's a great location.But I found out there are some a few frustrating things with this place.Don't book in on a Friday night!I realised later that people must go out for drinks after work, knowing they wouldn't have time to get home (or it was probably cheaper than a cab), so they'd book one of these for the night.The loudest snoring I have ever heard! I had anticipated for some noise, but even with earplugs, I didn't get much sleep. I did not book anywhere I stayed in Japan longer than 3 nights, just in case. On the last night here, I was so stuffed, I woke up when the cleaners moved in at 10am.Also, I thought the guy in the next pod was having a fight with himself, he was tossing and turning so much, my pod was shaking.There were other disturbances also, like people getting up at 3am to go catch a plane.Their name 9 Hours is apparently from the "three basic actions: take a shower, sleep, and get yourself dressed – one hour + seven hours + one hour". For me, I would say it more like: 15min + 3 hours + 10mins.You must also get out of the sleeping area by 10am each day. Not a problem if you are sightseeing every day. But it means you do have to remove all items from your Pod. You get to keep the same locked and can lock your bag there at all times.There is a locker room area (just outside the pod sleeping area) where you store your bag that is good. The only problem is, there is no room to open your bag to sort things out, like getting new clothes for the day. I used the floor to lay my bag open, but this can be tricky with everyone trying to get passed you.Men and women are on separate floors. The showers are on another floor. The reception is on another. There is a separate lift for men and women.So to get up in the morning, to have a shower and get dressed, I would have to grab some new clothes, go up the lift for a shower, go down the lift to my bag again, then go in the lift to reception (book in/out each day), then down to Ground to go out. I would say this would become tedious waiting for the lift, after a few nights, and trying to remember the items you need to take from your bag.My tip – have a few drinks.My recommendation: The Millennials Shibuya. Very friendly. So different. And was quiet. Did I mention FREE beer?

I can not fault this hotel/hostel, staying in a pod overnight intrigued me and I'm so glad that I found this place. Everything here was super clean and modern, when you check in they even give you a bag with towels, slippers and pajamas. The pod can get a little stuffy when the blinds are down just because there is no ventilation and the only area for improvement for me would be the pillows; I found them a little hard.The location is incredible, super easy to get to from the train station and alot of shops/restaurants are just walking distance away.Can not wait to stay here again next time I pass though Tokyo and would highly recommend this place to anyone wanting to experience pod life. If you stay for multiple nights you do have to check out then back in each day however you can keep the locker so you don't have to worry about taking your luggage out.One recommendation would be to take ear plugs, I have stayed in plenty of hostels/share rooms before and never have I shared a room with so many inconsiderate travellers... People were coming into the pod area up until midnight and talking loudly when entering and the noise started up again at 5am when people started waking up.

I have always wanted to try a capsule hotel out of sheer curiosity. However as they were often meant for inebriated Japanese salarymen after a heavy izakaya night , there was no chance I could ever try it until recently. The pod was comfy and the bath and showers were really tidy and clean. If you only need a night to rest your head, this could be the place. I would not recommend for long stays as one has to check out and then in again everyday.Light travelers , backpackers this is a good alternative to a night at the hostel. As I had large suitcase of luggage after s snowboarding trip, getting to the lockers and taking stuff was rather difficult and sometimes an inconvenience to other travelers. If you have not tried a capsule, is travelling with buddies or solo , and just want a rest for a night , i’d recommend 9 hours .

The capsule hotel looks modern and futuristic. It is located in popular place for K-Pop fanatics and Korean restaurants. It is perfect for travellers who will just need a place to sleep at night and visit the tourist spots in daytime. The only inconvenience is you need to check out every morning as they need to clean the capsule pods. If you are couple, the sleeping quarters for male and female are separated in different floors. TThis is perfect for solo travellers. Better book early to get cheaper price.

Fine for budget travellers and backpackers. This is very bare-bones experience. Not being able to lock the pod was very inconvenient, and so was having to check out every day. The lockers were not large enough and everything about staying there was awkward. The pods were too stuffy on the first night and I felt I was suffocating. THey kindly turned up the aircon though and it was more bearable. Other than that, showers were clean. THe reception area was very basic and staff not particularly knowledgeable.Also the male toilets weren't cleaned enough - they often smelled of urine.

It looks great and it's clean, but everything is at different levels and rooms (your cool-looking, cramped bed with little ventilation; your small locker; bathrooms). Reception desk is on the top floor and you always need to go there before you enter your level or leave the building. Everything is raw and there are no appliances or utensils. The capsule isn't well isolated, you hear other people. Location is kinda shady. The Millenials in Shibuya is a way better deal: your capsule is practically a room where you can hang out (in a 9hr capsule you can only lay down and sleep), offers a very cool space, kitchen, location in general. And included are: beverages, breakfasts and afternoon beer. Just doesn't compare. And if you travel with someone, it's also better just to get a hotel room than stay at 9hr. The view from the common area is spectacular but not worth staying at 9hr.

Many travelers had share their experience, check in- QR-code + locker + unpack - shower at different floor- not much space in the capsule.The sleeping quality is really good unless you have snoring mate in your room.The whole concept of the hotel is so advance and new to me, is very interesting.The location is great, near to SHin-Okubo station. 2-5 blocks with Family Mart and 7-11. Shin-Okubo is more to Korean Street to me.Cons is that, you need to unpack and pack every time you go change or shower, and that is tiring. For 1 day, is is nice to try.

I spent one night traveling alone as a woman. Great price, close to a trainstation, functional, and a whole floor with just women. Exactly what I needed! But unfortunately, I didn't count on it being a party-neighborhood (silly me) and the reception was pretty awful. The staff wasn't that nice and everyone was standing in line like the Sleepfactory it is. Other guests were kind of cold and loud as well in the common areas. Luckily, the sleeping area was really quiet and the matress and pillow was actually really nice. Didn't know how everything worked so I'll tell you guys: you sign in, get a QR-code for your locker, a number and a bag with slippers, a pyjama (which in didn't fit into cuz one size doesn't fit all) and a toothbrush. Pretty nice. You're expected to take the bag with you when you check out, not leave it in the locker. You go to your floor, put everything away and go to a different floor for showering, brushing teeth and another one for the communal area. If you want to leave, you first have to go all the way to the top to take another elevator that goes all the way down. You can only charge stuff in the common area. There is one japanese socket in the capsule but almost no place to put stuff in the capsule as it is meant for sleep only. Be prepared to climb over other guests as they undress in the aisle of the lockers. Have fun!

The hotel is divided by men and women as many things in Japan.There is one floor with the bathrooms and another floor with the capsules and the lockers.You can leave your personal belongings in a private locker that opens with a QR code that they give you when you check in.The capsule is very modern looking like. Feels like being in a spaceship. Its a very clean place. The space in the capsule it's actually ok.The main disadvantage is the noise. There are people snoring, coughing, coming in and out of the room the whole night. For me is was really impossible to sleep even half an hour... It was exhausting.The price is really low.Even if I was not able to sleep, for me it was a very different and worthy experience. It's for sure a one of a kind...

I really enjoy my 1 night stay the overall experience was great and smooth check in / out During check in you will be given a bag of pajamas / towel / toothbrush & slipper upon check out return the bag with towel and pajamas. The capsule come with single power outlet, a light dimmer i a pulling curtain in sleeping pods. I will come back again for my next trip again.

Stayed here for 3 nights in late April. The pods are amazing, very spacious with lots of room to sit up and wriggle around. Plug socket and light inside each with a blind you can pull down for privacy. The pillow is a bit hard as is filled with those tiny balls so not soft and squidy. You are given a bag with a towl, slippers, pyjamas and a toothbrush and paste in it when you check in, which is really handy. The lockers were brilliant, large enough to fit all of my bags. The showers were on a different floor to the bedrooms but it wasn’t a problem, the water pressure was good.The reception and social space is pretty cool, the view of Tokyo is amazing day and night.The worst thing about the hostel however, is that you have to check in and out every single day regardless of how long you’re staying. So at 10:00 you go to reception and hand your key and toiletries bag back. Then at 13:00 you can check in again. Although you can keep all of your belongings in the same locker as you will be given the same bed and everything again which is something at least. But to be honest I really do not understand the logic behind this policy. It was pretty annoying as you can never really have a lay in as you have to be out of your pod and checked out by 10:00.But apart from that the hostel was a great base for exploring Tokyo.

Even though it might get a little loud at night because you’re basically sharing a room with 40 people, I loved the design, the idea, the location and the showers! Free slippers and towels + toothpaste and toothbrush makes this better than a simple hostel.

Amazing and sweeping city views from the lobby/social area; comfortable (and surprisingly quiet sleeping area; huge shower stalls; locker space for shoes as well.Walking distance from train station. Really, really impressed.

This place is perfect for a one or two nighter stay through Tokyo. Totally Affordable.All you amenities are there. Lockers, Toilets & Sleep Pods are located on different floors to that of your shower rooms and the check-in facilities.You are given a locker like that of a gym change room to put your baggage in.The showers are large, private and clean. You are given a towel, toothbrush and PJs and slippers. You give back the towel and PJs at the end of the visitThe beds are super comfy and a power outlet is provided in your capsule bed to keep your phone or laptop charged. This is a quiet warm room where respect is shown to other fellow sleepers.Only things that need to be considered in this establishment is that the locker key needs to be more of a hard card than a flimsy card that is not waterproof.The elevator situation takes forever to interchange between floors.I will take the opportunity to stay here again as this provided more space than a lot of Air BnBs on offer and it is situated in one of the best areas of Tokyo with everything around.Staff were super helpful and there is a common area where you can recharge and plan your day out in Tokyo.I would rate this place a Big 9 out of 10.

Must do at least one night!!! If you are claustrophobic I advice not to consider. I am 5 feet tall and still had plenty of room to stretch out. I must admit they can be a bit stuffy but not to the point where you won’t be able to sleep. They are basic as they get one outlet, 2 slim shelves, light dimmer, pillow, & cover. Upon check in you receive a mesh bag with pj bottoms and top, tooth brush, tooth paste, big towel, small towels and slippers. There are dispensers to dispose of towels and slippers. Super modern, clean and organized. Floors separated my gender. Women’s elevators only go to women’s pods and showers, same for the men’s, middle one just goes from the first floor and lobby. Behind the reception there is a huge hangout area with a huge table as well as a bench along the wall for the non socializes as well as a big couch with an amazing day and night view as pictured below. Such a fun experience I wish we woulda done more than one night best part super cheap. Post check out at 10am they will hold your luggage until midnight. Also, a 2 minute walk from the train station, just turn right from the station and walk for a minute and you are there.

So, this was my first time at any such accommodations. I had concerns when I was first booking, but it was only for a night, so I thought it couldn't be that bad just for a night. Now I wouldn't have minded staying another night or two! The capsule hotel was spotless, super clean, modern, and fresh. Let's start with the capsules. Roomier than I thought. The ceiling has a nice enough clearance that you can actually sit up against the back wall and still have a bit of room. I was worried about it feeling a bit coffin-like, but was nothing like that at all. The bathroom and showers were very clean and roomy, and shampoo, conditioner, and body wash were all provided, as were slippers, a toothbrush, and various other sundries. You also are provided with a locker to put suitcases, bags, etc. Check in and check out were very easy and quick. My suggestion would be to map out how to get there. I took the JR Yamanote line and got off at Shinjuku. But I had to walk quite a ways, so take the Shin Okubu stop and it's much closer. Would stay again!

Very good location in Korean area, many restaurants and shops nearby.Bathroom was clean. Bed was comfortable with a blind but couldn't prevent noise from outside, might hear someone snoring at night.really recommend for solo traveller.

We had a lovely one night stay. It was a bit of fun to stay in a capsule hotel. Bathroom and showers are spacious and impeccably clean. Staff are very helpful at front desk when you check in. Lockers were a good size, big enough to fit a relatively large suitcase. The ladies floor was very quiet so we had a good night's sleep. It was quiet comfortable in the capsule, however it does get rather warm throughout the night after you close your privacy blind. My boyfriend said that the men's floor was a little noisier and didn't sleep as well as my sister and I did (snoring, chatting and alarms going off) but they enjoyed the experience. Breakfast is available in a cafe just down the road, they offer a simple but tasty breaky with unlimited juice, tea, coffee and soft drink. It was a clean and secure place to stay, perfect for individual travellers on a budget or for a different hotel experience.

Great location that is close to public transport and on a great train line that includes Ginza, Shibuya and Shinjuku. Must wander down to have ramen atRamen Zundou-ya Shinjuku Shop, a short 5 minute walk away.Lockers fit large suitcases, the only downside to capsule hotel is that its a pain to have to drag them in and out! Capsules are suprisingly comfy. Tip- take earplugs incase you are in close range of a snorer.Bathroom facilities seemed clean and there was always availability throughout my stay.

Staying at a capsule hotel is one of those tourist things you gotta try in Japan. I stayed for one night and had some reservations about how cramped the capsule would be (I’m 6’1 tall). I was pleasantly surprised that I could stretch out and roll around without issue. I slept quite well. The capsules are not sound proof as they do not have a door that seals shut, just a curtain that you pull down. I was woken a few times by people coming into their capsules. I had to set a morning alarm as I had a flight to catch, although I turned the volume down I know it woke some other people up. I wish they had sealing doors. The washrooms and showers were clean and always available. The lockers were more than large enough to store my stuff. The elevators are a bit odd. The reception is on the 8th floor. My room was on the 3rd. To get to the main floor you have to take one elevator to the 8th floor, then another elevator to the 1st. You have to do the same to get back to your room. Very odd!

Fortunately we stayed at Nine House Shinjuku North for only one night.First impressions of the place were very favourable as it is modern, minimalistic and appealing for anyone looking for the Japanese capsule experience.Each guest is given a towel, pyjamas and slippers upon arrival which seemed cool for a while but soon came to remind me of a very disturbing episode from 'Black Mirror'. This, combined with the single-sex dorms and infuriating elevator system, did nothing to help.The capsule itself is basic but spacious enough, however the frequent vibrations from the nearby train lines would disturb even the heaviest sleeper.On a positive note, this Nine Hours is very well located, has clean bathrooms which you won't need to queue for and a young, hipster vibe which might be enough for those travelling on a budget.

During my trip to Japan, I quickly racked up a lot of stays in capsule hotels. This was one of the last hotels I stayed in so maybe my expectations were quite high. The hotel was very average compared to the others. The futuristic design was fun, very close to Shin-Okubo station and the lockers were big. That’s about it. Customer service wasn’t great and the capsule was very warm at night even in the middle of winter. There were minimal amenities – no pillow options, coin laundry or a basic kitchenette.

If you're going to Japan you have to try out a capsule hotel for one night! This is the most up to date one we could find and it was at an excellent price. I probably wouldn't return here, but that's kinda the point... It's a once in a lifetime experience, just do it! It's full of Japanese business people which is what it's meant for of course!The men's quarters was a little noisy at night (coughing, farting etc... lol). I've been told the women's quarters was fine.It's also a little hot in the capsules. As I said, just do it once for the experience!

Nine Hours has a futuristic minimalistic design. As compared to the other capsule hotels, Nine Hours gave off a really clean and memorable experience. There were plenty of shower rooms and was surprised at how big the washroom was. The locker was big enough for my luggage too. Liked that there were separate lifts for different genders too, which provided security to ladies. The pods were not very soundproof though.

This was my first time sleeping in a capsule, and nine hours definitely delivered a memorable experience for me. Their system is fairly easy to understand, and the staff there give out easy instructions in english to help us. The capsules and bathrooms are clean and tidy. This place is also close to heaps of shopping places. It was easy for me to travel from this hotel to see Godzilla's head. Nine Hours is good for a 1 or 2 night stay, definitely not for longer.

I enjoyed the futuristic design of the hotel and also how clean it was. I am happy that my luggage fitted in the cabinet so I didn't need to worry to leave it near the reception. The bathrooms were also very clean with all the toiletries. It is a bit different style of accommodation as you have shared space there and sleep in a relatively small capsule. However, I enjoyed this experience and if I have a quick trip to Tokyo I would probably choose it again as it is cheap, clean and safe. I also write a deeper review on my blog Explorewithdiana so you can check it. ;-) I would recommend it for a very short stay to experience something new. Perfect for budget traveller, located near metro station, the area is safe at night.

You get what you paid for. If you are looking for cheap accommodations with clean beds, good showers and a place near a train stop, this is it. It is superbly clean.As with staying in capsule hotels would need to understand and be prepared to sleep with some noise of people whispering conversations, snores, phone alarms etc.  Did not really like to check in and out everyday as I had to drag my bag out of the locker and into the public area which has no security and then leaving it there until you are able to check in again in the afternoon. Leave behind only what you are able to lose, just in case.Great for a cheap alternative but understand that it will be lacking on the "human" aspects. I found the front desk to be impolite. We arrived before noon and enquired about check in, we were given a unfriendly frown and an abrupt answer that no check in before a certain time. Look, there is no harm is asking and this is the first time we are in a capsule hotel, some direction would be appreciated. Having travelled to Tokyo before, I would say this would be the least pleasant encounter i ever had in Japan.

This was my first time staying in a capsule hotel. It was an enjoyable experience, though I have no other to compare it to. The hotel and capsule were clean and tidy and I had no problems. The only minor issue I had was I was not given my "essentials bag" when I checked in so I had to go back and ask for this.

First time staying in a capsule and thanks goodness it is a good experience. Within 5 minutes walk from Shin-Okubo, the whole place is quite hi-tech. Placed your luggage in the locker provided. Clean toilets and shower rooms. PJs, towel, slippers are provided. The capsule wasn't too small and don't feel claustrophobic. Strong Wifi. The only issue is the capsule's blinds is either fully open or fully close. It could be better if we could have it 3/4 close to allow better air ventilation.

Like many others I just stayed here for the experience. Clean facilities and friendly staff. There are pros (good location, good price, quality toiletries, novelty factor) and cons (too hot for me and no ability to change the temperature, annoying fellow travellers {two people on the night I stayed had to be angrily told to put their phones on silent while they listened to tv shows on full volume!}). There is literally no soundproofing whatsoever so this shall remain an experience I once had, and won't be repeated :)

Oh this is a beautiful place. Very contemporary, space-agey and minimalist. It is centrally located, and at a very short walk, about 3-4 mins walk from Shin-Okubo station. You can use your JR Pass to travel to and from this station for free (if majority of your list includes visiting Shinjuku, Harajuku, Shibuya). This area is called Korea town of Tokyo (just in case you are interested in exploring that) and is very lively. Everything is exactly as described and seen in pictures. The capsules are very comfortably spacious, do not even think twice that you will feel stuffy. You locker will be outside your capsule room, and shower area on another floor. Beautiful view of the city from the reception floor.

I really enjoyed the pod experience - baggage storage before checkin, super clean facilities, you get PJs, slippers, and a towel and the pod is super cool. Spacious, very nice showers. I had a decent sleep, would have been nice to be able to control the aircon. My dad stayed in the men's ward and he had a horrible night with people going in and out throughout the night. My colleague who used to live in Japan later told me that the men's is mainly used by business men who have gone out drinking and missed their last train home...

You will be greeted by an amazing view from reception and friendly staff.Place was remarkably quiet in the sleeping areas. Great location. They supply you with a towel. So leave your bags in Shinjuku station. Walk and party your way to 9 hours. Rest up, and head back.

Staying in nine hours was my third capsule/sleeping pod experience in Japan. Though they dont have much facilities at their premises but the hotel is at a prime location, very neat and clean and having 2 minuets walk to Shin Okubo station.The staff was very cooperative and helpful. You can say it is a digital hotel, everything was was systematic. Like other capsules they have the same rules of check in-out. The good thing is, that all showers are private at 7th floor for Men. Locker space is also good, you can lift the middle rack up if your luggage is large. If you are staying more than one night, you can leave your luggage in the locker but not in the sleeping pod. The only thing I didn’t like that pods were not having the adjustable fans, you have to accept whatever is the pod temperature. I felt little suffocation at first night but it was okay later on.Online booking is advisable before your stay so you won’t pay more money.

review_body: It was very interesting experience. I heard a lot about capsule hotels, but I was scared that it will be an awful and cheap hostel. Actually, it's 8-floors new building, very technological, stylish and cozy. The price is good enough- 4000 yen/day and you can use everything in the hotel. Next time in Tokyo I'll try to spend more than 1 night in this awesome place.

My husband and I stayed here for one night as we wanted to try the capsule hotel experience! Before we arrived my husband was a bit uncertain about what sleeping in a tiny pod would be like and wasn’t 100% keen, but we both loved Nine Hours at Shinjuku.Everything was simple and efficient. We loved the free pyjamas, the showers were great and our capsules were really spacious and comfy. It was fairly busy when we stayed but I wasn’t disturbed by any noise at all during the night and the capsule felt very private once I pulled the blind down. There was also a common area so there is somewhere outside the capsule to sit and chat etc. Overall it was a great experience and we were sad to leave. We would happily stay there again. It was more money than we would usually spend on a hotel (we are budget travellers and usually stay in v cheap hostels), but it was good value for what we got.

Have to check in and check out everyday. I like the design and neat. The hot water for shower is really really hot(cant adjust). This is only problem for me. Around the hotel has alot of convenience shop (7/11, family mart, lawson and etc). If u r k-pop lover then u should stay this hotel. All korean restaurants and korean mall around there...

Good location.Practical, clean and convenient option of what you can expect from a capsule hotel.Service is highly efficient, main room is surprisingly warm and enjoyable.The bed is clean, relatively spacious but noisy - as expected.Bathroom is modern and clean.Overall - recommended.

Clean capsules and thoroughly functional, this is a good capsule hotel. The only downside, as with all capsule hotels, is how loud it can be with people coming and going at all times due to flights. The pods are not individually air conditioned and the bedding is not the most comfortable but for a quick stay it is a great option.

We stayed one night at this capsule hotel and we were pleasantly surprised. Very clean, very modern and felt very safe. Dorms are divided into female and male. No combination - both good but bad for us who are a couple.Showers and toilets are on a separate floor and was super clean - very impressive.Sleeping pods looked like something out of a sci-fi movie! Ok comfortable beds - very uncomfy pillow. The hall was also a bit loud with people ignoring the quiet signs. Good location. Overall a very good cheap option for a night or two. Can recommend it to backpackers and couples.

I must have been about 9 myself, too long ago to remember now. But what I do still remember was seeing this kind of capsule hotel on a bbc travel programme. I knew then that one day I wanted to visit Japan & stay in one of these. It seems to me to be the most futuristic hotel, close to the sic-fi experiences I loved off the movies. So... 31 years later I made it. <3 I must say sleeping 50 to a room would be a nightmare in most countries, but the Japanese being Japanese, they're so polite, quiet & considerate. Not even a whisper. I stayed here two nights and it's surprisingly comfortable, not claustrophobic at all. Great comfy bed, amazing showers, high tech toilets. Nice little lounge suits to put on & plenty of free toiletries. Lockers were small but big enough. Great neighbourhood, one of the best I reckon. I felt a mild earthquake which didn't phase me at all. I would definitely stay here again but there are some downers. You have to check out and in again daily. Plus men & women are separate. I was a solo traveler but it would bother me if i was with my partner.

This capsule hostel can offer an affordable option for accomodation in Tokyo excelling in the basic services: spotlessly clean, sophisticated design, comfortable and spacious sleeping pod ( despite the concept, the pod has enough s), pyjamas, slippers and towels provided, perfect shower. Great location a few metres from the Yamanote line and very close to the buzziest spots of Shinjuku but far enough. Plenty of dining options just next to the main entrance and a lot of "ambiance" on the street.I would believe this would be the perfect option to recommend if only I had not experienced the most unpleasant experience with some of the staff ( ironically the female staff are polite and helpful, not the male staff I encountered). If you have the slightest deviation from the schedule they set ( like you sleep past the check out hour which can frequently happen if you're coming from another continent and are heavily jet lagged), then the staff will treat in the rudest, unpleasant way that make you feel miserable. I will not recommend this place to my acquaintances to trust this place as their " home abroad" for a couple of nights. Without the "human touch" their staff displays, sleeping here feels like being in a spaceship. And there are plenty of clean, affordable, centric and "human" options in Tokyo to choose from.

The capsules are exactly like the pictures shown by the property and everything is very clean. Each person gets a locker which has pajamas, flip flops, towels, and toothbrush inside as well as space to leave your luggage. The rooms, toilets, and showers are divided between male and female with different floors as well as elevators. Female rooms are located on two different floors and showers are located on a third floor. It's convenient and fast to move from one floor to the other. The showers are quite big and provided with shampoo, conditioner, and space to put your clothes. Inside each capsule, you can find a socket and you have a curtain to close your capsule when sleeping. The capsules look much bigger than in the picture and are very comfortable. The pillow is a little thin and hard, different from what I am used to finding in hotels, but impressively was comfortable. In the reception, there is a common area with tables and chair, simple and clean.Wifi is good and works well!It's close to Shinjuku station, around 10 minutes walking. There are a lot of restaurants, mini markets, 7Elevens around.You need to check-in and check-ou every day. This is the reason we stayed there only 1 night. I think would be a hassle to stay in this hotel for 5 days having to check-out every day at 11 AM and check-in at 1 PM.

My most recent trip to Tokyo was a quick 3 day trip and I needed to be near the Shinjuku area. Being that this was a very last minute trip, I opted to keep the cost down by booking a capsule hotel. Nine Hours Shinjuku-North recently opened in March 2017 so I decided to try it out.Nine Hours Shinjuku-North is located about a 1-2 minute walk from the Shin Okubo station on the JR Yamanote (Green) line. This is 1 stop after Shinjuku station. It is also about 10 minutes walk from Okubo station on the Chuo line and 10-15 minutes walk from Higashi-Shinjuku station which is serviced by Toei and Tokyo Metro. The surrounding neighborhood is known as being largely korean and has a plethora of shops and restaurants. A Don Quijote is nearby and Golden Gai can be reached within 20 minutes of walking.Once at the building, take the elevator from the ground floor to the reception in the 8th floor. Check in is starts at 1pm everyday and checkout is by 10am the following day. Like most other capsule hotels, even if you have a consecutive night stay you still have to check out and check in. For consecutive night guests, your bags can remain in your locker during the checkout period. At check in you will be issued a paper card with a QR code which grants you access to your locker. Floors are separated by gender and there are only 3 elevators. 1 is from the ground floor to reception and the other two is for male and female floors. For males, floor are on 3 or 4 and determined by your keycard. Once on your proper floor, locker storage and sleeping capsules can be accessed. You unlock your locker with your QR card given at check in. While others opened flawlessly, mine always had trouble scanning and needed to be held for 10-20 seconds. This was even acknowledged by some staff members as buggy and not normal. The locker easily held my 28" check in bag, shoes, and other goods. Disposable slippers are issued and must be used while indoors (bathroom, capsule area, locker area). Guests are issued a body towel, face towel, and toothbrush with toothpaste everyday. You are also provided sleeping wear. For those who have oversized bags that do not fit in lockers, it may be stored in the lounge area.The pod itself is very spacious and I never felt constrained. Pods are configured in a 2 level staggered system. You are issued a blanket and Japanese buckwheat pillow. There is 1 AC outlet and the light control. In accordance with Japanese laws, it is illegal for pods to lock and as such there is no door. Instead, a blind comes down to ensure privacy. I did find that it got stuffy for me and ventilation wasn't as constant as I thought it would be. As such, I slept without a shirt to cool myself down. The pod experience is hit or miss. I came i knowing that it would be directly influenced by others. While everyone tried to stay quiet within the area, sounds could be heard throughout the night be it someone's phone going off, someone entering or exiting the pod, coughing, snoring, or farting. I came prepared with ear plugs which came in handy. None were provided by the hotel.The 7th floor is the shower and washroom with provided body wash, shampoo, and conditioner. The 8th floor is the reception area and just behind it is the lounge area. The lounge is equipped with 4 desks, a long bar table, and a long wood table with plenty of seats and power outlets throughout. There are also benches that face the floor to ceiling windows which offer a beautiful view of Shinjuku, especially at night. The lounge area is the only area within the hotel where food may be consumed. Wifi is free and reaches all floors. Finally, the lounge area is also where bags may be left, even after checkout. Note that this is unattended although Japan is very safe. Overall I left with my budget-minded experience very satisfied. The location was excellent. If I could leave a few recommendations it would be for the caspule to have an additional AC outlet or a dedicated USB outlet. I would also prefer if the capsule had better ventilation and a possible alarm system built into the capsule. Finally, although Japan is overall safe and the hotel has limited space, if the baggage storage area could be monitored by staff it would give the extra peace of mind. I highly recommend Nine Hours Shinjuku-North to all those interested.

The staff is very helpful and the structure is very clean and well organized, with divided lifts for female and male areas, lockers just close to the sleeping pods and big and comfortable showers.Really loved the simple and neat design.Location is just close to Shino-Okubo JR station, one stop from Shinjuku, so really close to the main attractions.We stayed two nights and had to check out and in again the next day - to facilitate the cleanings, not such a big deal since we had small and easy to pack backpacks.The only negative comes when your capsule neighbors are inconsiderate (some girls were laughing at 1 am, another was packing INSIDE the capsule really early in the morning, come on, there are other areas to do all these things!). So the recommendation is: bring your earplugs!

If you are ever stuck in the Narita airport, go to the airport NINE hour hotel....They have cool pods that you sleep in, super quiet and as the rest of Japan, CLEAN. You get a robe and slippers to sleep in. The pods are not claustraphobic as I had feared. There is actually plenty of room above nad beside you. Each shower is private and locked..and again CLEAN, and it includes body soap, shampoo and conditioner. I was so refreshed for my flight the next morning. I am so glad i had this experience.

Spent one night in Nine Hours Capsule Hotel, for wanting the experience. Being prepared for a quite uncomfortable stay, I was surprised how good it was. Especially if you consider the price (I payed €21,31 for one night). Easy check in, very clean (and many) restrooms, showers and pods (capsules) and big lockers which easily fitted my large backpack (70l) and normal sized rugsack. They provide you with slippers, pajamas and towels. The pods have a plug and a dim light. They were surprisingly large, so if I'd wanted I could have stored my rugsack in my pod. Everyone was being very quite. The only downside I could think of is that you shut the pod with a roll up curtain, so you can here everything outside your pod. Thankfully by that I only mean people walking to their pods and some alarms in the morning from people waking up. Plus you could feel a little movement when people would lie down in their pods. And last, the overnight stay is gender separated. There are even separated elevators for the men and women floors. It surely was no problem since my boyfriend and I only stayed one night, but if you stay for a longer period of time it might not be as fun. Though some might prefer it that way. The location is right next to the station and I could leave my luggage at the reception for as long as I wanted. Overall I highly recommend it if you want a capsule experience or want to visit Tokyo on a low budget.

This is by far the best capsule hotel I've ever seen and is worth it just for the experience for one night. The design and thought put into the place is exceptional. Don't expect hotel comforts though. You check in, get a pod & locker key, you then put your bags in the locker and either head to the lounge or out.. or change into the provided clothes to go to the showers floor which are each clean and lockable, or head to your sleep pod which is also clean. It has a power outlet, a light dimmer and aircon outlets. It's illegal for sleeping pods to be lockable in Japan. Instead you have a privacy screen you pull down which can kind of only be opened from inside. As a result you can here muffled noises of people coming in/out or snoring, but that's wot every capsule hotel. Enjoy!

This capsule hotel is very well run and super clean. Conveniently located near a JR station and lots of great places to eat. You get PJs, a towel, slippers and toiletries. The bathroom has very clean, individual shower cubicles with body wash, shampoo and conditioner. Also has hairdryers available to use. The pods are roomy and pretty comfy. Can be a noisy night if you have inconsiderate people coming in noisily at all hours. Pretty hard for the staff to predict or control that as it is clearly written everywhere for people to be quiet and considerate. Aside from this, it is convenient, cheap and makes for a pretty good experience.

This was our first time in a pod hotel and it was a pleasant one. The pods were clean and the shower and facilities were of a high standard. The communal area was large and had free wifi with lots of sitting space so overall a very good experience. The 2 negatives were that on the friday morning there were a number of people leaving for work at around 5:30 - 6 which unfortunately meant that everyone on that particular floor was also awake at that time. The weekend didn't seem to be as much of a problem but earplugs would definitely be an advantage. 2nd minor issue was having to check out and back in each day. This meant a new locker and new pod each day which wasn't really a problem other than all of our bags having to be in the communal area all day unsupervised. Overall a good stay for the amount we paid.

You know what you're in for when you made the booking! As I was forced to book this last resort because all the other 5 star hotels in town were fully booked due to the peak of Sakura season, my choice proved me wrong at the end. This WAS a very authentic experience and I definitely urge everyone who's in Tokyo to try it at least once in your life. You check in at 8F where all the registration process is through an iPad. The "room keys" they issue you is a simple paper ticket with a QR code on it which unlocks your locker. After registration is done, the gentleman and the ladies are separated, in which they were not encounter each other whatsoever unless they all go back to 8F "lobby".I went down to the ladies side of the building and the capsules are split evenly between two floors- 5&6 I believe. You will enter a locker room where you will store your luggage and change your shoes to indoor slippers. And in the locker will be towels and shower amenities for you to use during your stay.After you leave your luggage, directly ahead is the capsules in 2 rows. I was lucky to get a capsule on the upper bunk, but be ware that the capsule "doors" don't lock! It's just a plastic window-pane like panel that pulls up and down, it is against the rule to lock it in any way whatsoever. The capsules are actually more spacious than I had prepared myself to be, so tame your claustrophobic fear and go try it!Shower rooms are on a separate floor 7F, the individual shower rooms are super duper clean and upscale, it's the idea of a school dorm actually, except for old ladies like myself. You will encounter and see so many different kinds of people come and go as you sit there blow drying your hair. There is ONE shower room that has a bathtub to enjoy but it is usually occupied.All in all, it is an experience everyone should try while in Tokyo, nine hours is a safe bet as it is a local chain so it was well kept and easily accessed.
